banner.text:
This time we need two parts for our app.
Click 'Add Parts' on the right.

tooltips.text: Click on Sticker to add it to your app

banner.text: A sticker has been added to your canvas! Click 'Add Parts' again to add the mouse part.

tooltips.text: Click on Mouse to add it to your app.

banner.text: Now letâ€™s add some code to style the sticker. Open the sticker tray.
Drag the set sticker block into your code.
Connect it inside the app starts event.
Change the first input from animals to music.
Change the second input from Bell to Trumpet
Open the Sticker tray again.
Grab the set size block.
Connect under the last block.
Open the Variables tray to get a simple number block.
Grab the number block.
Plug it inside the set size block.

This number will set the size of the sticker (as a % of its original size).
Change it from 0 to 130.
Now to set up some styles for drawing. Open the draw tray.
Grab the fill color block.
Connect it beneath the last block.
Click to change the color. Pick any color you like! #FFDC00#DC00FF#00FFDC
Open the Control tray to set up your animation loop.
Grab the every 1 second block.
Connect it beneath your last block.
Change seconds to frames.
Now to set up a really quick paint effect! Open the draw tray.

Remember that to draw with code, you move the pen first.
Grab the move to block.
Connect it inside the loop.
Weâ€™re going to move the drawing pen to the mouse coordinates again. Open the Mouse tray.
Grab the X position block.
Connect it to the move to x input.
Now for the Y position. Open the Mouse tray again.
Grab the Y position block.
Connect it to the move to y input.
Open the draw tray â€¦
â€¦ and grab the circle block.
Connect it beneath the move to.
Try it out by moving your mouse around on the canvas. It leaves a trail, but all the circles are the same size.
Letâ€™s add some randomness to the circle radius! Open the Math tray.
Grab the random number block.
Connect it up to the circle radius input.
Change 10 to 20.
Try it out again by moving your mouse around on the canvas. Thatâ€™s more like it!
Now weâ€™re going to add some clever logic to build a sticker game. Ready?
Open the Events tray.
Grab an event block.
Drop the block anywhere on your code space. Itâ€™s a good idea to put it below the code block youâ€™ve already written.
Change the event from app starts to Sticker is clicked.

Now any code you put inside this block will run when the sticker is clicked.
This is going to eb the basis of our simple game!
Open the Sticker tray.
Grab the move to block.
Connect it inside your new event.
Now open the Math tray to get another random number block.
Grab the random number block.
Connect it to the move to x input.
Change the second number from 10 to 450.
Now for the Y position. Open the math tray again.
Grab another random number block.
Connect this one to the move to y input.
Change the second number from 10 to 325 on this one.
Have a look at that line of code. What do you think will happen when you click on the sticker? Try it out!

When you click the sticker, letâ€™s also change the color of your paint brush.
Open the draw tray.
Grab the fill color block.
Connect it under your last block.
Open the Color tray â€¦
â€¦ and grab a color with block.
Connect it to the fill color input (place it over the top of the placeholder color block thatâ€™s there).
Change the color mode from rgb (red, green, blue) to hsv (hue, saturation, value).
Open the Math tray again.
Grab the random number block.
Connect it to the color with hue input.
Change the second value from 10 to 35.
Try clicking the sticker a few times now. Do you see the paint color change?
Finally, when you click the sticker, weâ€™ll use a random number to decide if the sticker changes or not. This kind of probability is the basis of thousands of computer games.
Open the Sticker tray.
Grab the set to block.
Connect it beneath the fill color block.
Change the first value from animals to music.
Change the second value from Bell to Trumpet
Now for the random number. Open the Variables tray.
Grab the set variable block.
Connect it beneath your other code.
Open the Math tray again.
Grab the random number block.
Connect it to the set variable input.
Open the Logic tray.
Grab the if block â€¦
â€¦ and connect it beneath your other code.
Now for the other part of our if code. Open the Logic tray again.
Grab this block â€¦
â€¦ and connect it to the if block input.
Change = to > greater than
Open the Variables tray.
Grab the item block.
Connect it to the left hand input of your if statement.
Open the Variables tray again.
Grab a simple number block.
Plug it into the right hand side of your if statement.
Change 0 to 9.

Now any code you put inside the if block will run if the random number is above 9.
That means the code will run one time in ten.
Now for the code to put inside the if statement. Open the Sticker tray.
Grab the set sticker block.
Connect it inside your if block.
Change the first value from animals to music.
Change the second value from Bell to Sax.
Try it out! Count how many times you have to click the sticker before it changes. Challenge a friend to see if they can change the sticker in less clicks!
Great work! Youâ€™ve used logic, drawing, events, and random numbers to make a game.
